citations.narrative:
No regulated activities may be conducted until a USDA license/registration is obtained.
The facility is conducting regulated activity without a license from USDA APHIS Animal Care under the Animal Welfare
Act (AWA). On September 21, 2024, a search was conducted by a USDA inspector at the Renaissance Fair in Shakopee,
MN. Animals of Walton's Hollow were exhibiting multiple animals including 8 goats, 2 ferrets, 2 pigs, 1 cow, 1
Llama/alpaca cross, 3 ducks, 4 chickens, 1 sheep, 2 guinea pigs, and 2 rabbits. An admission fee is charged to get in to
the Renaissance Fair. Exhibiting a combination of these species in these numbers is an activity that requires a license
under the AWA.
An application for licensure was received by USDA APHIS Animal Care in March/April 2022, but the applicant never
scheduled a first prelicense inspection and has to date failed to obtain a license. Conducting regulated activity without a
USDA license does not comply with the Animal Welfare Act or ensure that APHIS officials can assess the care of the
animals. Continuing to conduct regulated activity without a license is a serious violation of the Animal Welfare Act. No
regulated activities may be conducted until a USDA license/registration is obtained.

Two rabbits and two guinea pigs are being housed in the same enclosure together. Housing rabbits in the same enclosure
as guinea pigs can lead to compatibility issues and can also contribute to the spread of disease. The licensee must
separate the rabbits from the guinea pigs and must not house the rabbits with any other species of animal.

During an inspection, a goat was observed to be able to get out of its enclosure. An enclosure that is unable to contain the
animals may result in the animals escaping from the enclosure, potentially resulting in the animals getting injured, killed,
or not being found. The enclosure must be repaired to contain the animals. Until repaired, the enclosure should not be
used to house any regulated animals.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
End of report.
Additional Inspectors:
Shoshana Tanenbaum, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.1(a)(1) 
   
Requirements and application. 
No regulated activities may be conducted until a USDA license/registration is obtained. 
 
The facility is conducting regulated activity without a license from USDA APHIS Animal Care under the Animal Welfare 
Act (AWA). On September 21, 2024, a search was conducted by a USDA inspector at the Renaissance Fair in Shakopee, 
MN. Animals of Walton's Hollow were exhibiting multiple animals including 8 goats, 2 ferrets, 2 pigs, 1 cow, 1 
Llama/alpaca cross, 3 ducks, 4 chickens, 1 sheep, 2 guinea pigs, and 2 rabbits. An admission fee is charged to get in to 
the Renaissance Fair. Exhibiting a combination of these species in these numbers is an activity that requires a license 
under the AWA.  
 
An application for licensure was received by USDA APHIS Animal Care in March/April 2022, but the applicant never 
scheduled a first prelicense inspection and has to date failed to obtain a license. Conducting regulated activity without a 
USDA license does not comply with the Animal Welfare Act or ensure that APHIS officials can assess the care of the 
animals. Continuing to conduct regulated activity without a license is a serious violation of the Animal Welfare Act. No 
regulated activities may be conducted until a USDA license/registration is obtained. 
3.58(a) 
   
Classification and separation. 
Two rabbits and two guinea pigs are being housed in the same enclosure together. Housing rabbits in the same enclosure 
as guinea pigs can lead to compatibility issues and can also contribute to the spread of disease. The licensee must 
separate the rabbits from the guinea pigs and must not house the rabbits with any other species of animal. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
During an inspection, a goat was observed to be able to get out of its enclosure. An enclosure that is unable to contain the 
animals may result in the animals escaping from the enclosure, potentially resulting in the animals getting injured, killed, 
or not being found. The enclosure must be repaired to contain the animals. Until repaired, the enclosure should not be 
used to house any regulated animals.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative. 
 
End of report. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Shoshana Tanenbaum, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
